page.title: 04THE HUNTING LODGE,CHINGFORD
page.content: Epping Forest was a royal hunting ground where the deer were preserved for the kings and queens to hunt.In 1540 Henry VIII bought more land at Chingford to make a royal park. Henry,who loved hunting,became too fat to ride after deer and so had to remain in his "great stone deigne" or standing,now called the Hunting Lodge on the hill above Chingford Plain, where the royal party could assemble to watch the hunt or shoot deer which were driven towards them. The lodge was completed in 1543.All joints and nails were made of wood. When Queen ElizabethI became Queen she preferred to hunt from the lodge and it became known as the Hunting Lodge.The story is that she rode up the staircase on horseback when the Spanish Armada were defeated.The lodge is now a museum open to the public.
